This article aims to provide a comprehensive overview of key aspects of tax filing and compliance in the Indian context.

unnormalised: One of the primary tasks for taxpayers is to determine their applicable Income Tax Slab. For individuals below 60 years of age, the new tax regime offers slabs starting from 0% up to Rs. 3 lakh, rising progressively to 30% for income exceeding Rs. 15 lakh. The old tax regime, however, allows for various deductions and exemptions, such as investments under Sec 80C, HRA, and other applicable allowances. The choice between the old and new regimes should be made after carefully considering individual circumstances and tax planning strategies. For senior citizens (60-80 years), different tax slabs apply, with a higher basic exemption limit.

unnormalised: The deadline for filing Income Tax Returns (ITR) for individuals not subject to audit is generally July 31st of the assessment year. For assessment year 2024-25, this date is July 31, 2024. However, taxpayers who are subject to audit have an extended deadline, typically October 31st of the assessment year. It is essential to gather all necessary documents, such as Form 16, Form 26AS, bank statements, and investment proofs, well in advance to facilitate timely filing. Delayed filing can attract penalties under Section 234F of the Income Tax Act.
normalised: The deadline for filing Income Tax Returns (I-T-R) for individuals not subject to audit is generally July thirty first of the assessment year. For assessment year two thousand twenty four to two thousand twenty five, this date is July thirty first, two thousand twenty four. However, taxpayers who are subject to audit have an extended deadline, typically October thirty first of the assessment year. It is essential to gather all necessary documents, such as Form sixteen, Form twenty six A-S, bank statements, and investment proofs, well in advance to facilitate timely filing. Delayed filing can attract penalties under Section two hundred and thirty four F of the Income Tax Act.

unnormalised: Tax Deducted at Source (TDS) plays a significant role in tax compliance. Employers deduct TDS from employees' salaries and deposit it with the government. Similarly, banks deduct TDS on interest income exceeding Rs. 40,000 (Rs. 50,000 for senior citizens). Form 26AS, available on the Income Tax Department's e-filing portal, provides a consolidated statement of TDS deducted on your behalf. It is crucial to reconcile the TDS details in Form 26AS with your income and deductions to ensure accurate reporting in the ITR.

Form twenty six A-S, available on the Income Tax Department's e-filing portal, provides a consolidated statement of T-D-S deducted on your behalf. It is crucial to reconcile the T-D-S details in Form twenty six A-S with your income and deductions to ensure accurate reporting in the I-T-R.

unnormalised: Advance tax is another important aspect of tax compliance for individuals whose estimated tax liability for the financial year exceeds Rs. 10,000. Advance tax is payable in installments throughout the financial year. The due dates for advance tax payments are typically June 15, September 15, December 15, and March 15. Failure to pay advance tax or underpayment can attract interest under Section 234B and 234C of the Income Tax Act. It is advisable to accurately estimate your income and tax liability to avoid such charges.

unnormalised: E-filing of ITR has become the standard mode of filing in India. The Income Tax Department's e-filing portal offers a user-friendly interface to file your ITR online. You can either upload the ITR form after filling it offline or fill it directly on the portal. Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) or Electronic Verification Code (EVC) can be used to authenticate the ITR. Aadhaar-based OTP is a convenient and widely used method for EVC. After successful e-filing, it is important to verify your ITR, which can be done online or by sending a physical copy of ITR-V to the Centralized Processing Centre (CPC), Bengaluru, within 120 days of filing.
normalised: E-filing of I-T-R has become the standard mode of filing in India. The Income Tax Department's e-filing portal offers a user-friendly interface to file your I-T-R online. You can either upload the I-T-R form after filling it offline or fill it directly on the portal. Digital Signature Certificate (D-S-C) or Electronic Verification Code (E-V-C) can be used to authenticate the I-T-R. Aadhaar-based O-T-P is a convenient and widely used method for E-V-C. After successful e-filing, it is important to verify your I-T-R, which can be done online or by sending a physical copy of I-T-R-V to the Centralized Processing Centre (C-P-C), Bengaluru, within one hundred and twenty days of filing.

unnormalised: Recent amendments to the Income Tax Act have introduced various changes impacting tax filing and compliance. For instance, the Faceless Assessment Scheme aims to bring transparency and efficiency to the assessment process. Taxpayers should stay updated with the latest notifications and circulars issued by the Income Tax Department to ensure compliance with the current regulations. Consulting a tax professional or CA is always recommended, especially for complex tax matters. Keep records of all your financial transactions and tax-related documents for at least 8 years.
